documents.title: afternoon summary
text: a guardian/icm poll suggests that at least two thirds of voters would oppose the uk paying an exit bill to the eu of â£ 10bn or more .

voters would also oppose another compromise theresa may may have to accept as part of the brexit deal , giving the european court of justice continuing control over uk law during the transition period .
( see 4.16pm . )

spain has urged the british government to keep a cool head in the negotiations over the future of gibraltar after the former conservative leader michael howard suggested theresa may would be prepared to go to war to protect the territory as margaret thatcher once did over the falklands .

theresa may has defended cuts to bereaved family payments as fair to taxpayers in a week where families with a terminally ill parent could see thousands wiped off their benefits if the parent survives beyond new rules introduced later this week .
the proposed funding cuts in the government 's new spending formula for schools in england will disproportionately affect more deprived areas , according to a labour analysis .
tax changes coming into effect this month could be worth â£ 20bn to big businesses and wealthy individuals over the next five years , labour has said .

as the press association reports , drawing on the government 's own figures , shadow chancellor john mcdonnell said the changes will involve tax giveaways worth â£ 2.5bn this year alone , at a time when in-work benefits for the low-paid are being reduced by billions of pounds .

the reduction in corporation tax to 19 % last saturday , announced in the 2015 budget , will be worth â£ 2.28bn in this financial year and , coupled with a further reduction to 18 % in 2020/21 , will deliver a total â£ 17.7bn in tax breaks to companies over five years , said mcdonnell .

meanwhile , inheritance tax breaks , also announced in 2015 and coming into effect this month , which will allow married couples to pass on estates worth â£ 1m free of death duties , will be worth â£ 265m this year and â£ 2.8bn over the next five years .
and the extension of capital gains tax reliefs announced in last year 's budget will be worth â£ 45m this year and â£ 220m over the period to 2021/22 .
that 's all from me for today .
thanks for the comments .

documents.title: at least two thirds of voters would oppose paying eu 'exit bill ' of â£ 10bn or more , poll suggests
text: last week , as theresa may published her article 50 letter , she effectively confirmed that she accepts she will have to compromise with the eu over certain areas to get a brexit deal .
as part of the last guardian/icm polling , we asked about some of the possible compromises that the government may have to make .
and the answers should make worrying reading in downing street .
although voters would find some potential compromises acceptable , they are strongly opposed to others - particularly those involving making multi-billion pound payments to the eu to leave .
we asked about six potential compromises .
here are the results .
potential exit payments the biggest row will almost be about the uk 's exit bill .
the eu wants the uk to pay its share of current eu budget liabilities and it has been widely reported that they will set the figure at ¬60bn ( around â£ 50bn ) .
the financial times ' alex barker has written a good centre for european reform paper explaining how this sum is calculated .
british ministers insist â£ 50bn is just an opening bid , and so instead we asked what people would feel about exit payments set at a lower level .

respondents were asked about paying an exit fee ' of up to [ â£ 3bn/â£ 10bn/â£ 20bn ] , as a one-off or in instalments , as the uk 's contribution to spending commitments made by the eu when the uk was a member .

â£ 3bn acceptable : 33 % not acceptable : 46 % do n't know : 21 % â£ 10bn acceptable : 15 % not acceptable : 64 % do n't know : 21 % â£ 20bn acceptable : 10 % not acceptable : 70 % do n't know : 20 % at least two thirds of voters think paying â£ 10bn or more to the eu as an exit bill , would be unacceptable , a poll suggests .
some 64 % would find a â£ 10bn bill unacceptable and 70 % would find a â£ 20bn bill unacceptable , even though that sum is less than half what eu leaders are currently demanding .
only a third of voters would find paying a â£ 3bn exit bill acceptable , a poll suggests .
( one recent times report [ paywall ] said brexit-supporting cabinet ministers think â£ 3bn is the most britain should pay . )
according to a report in the sunday times yesterday ( paywall ) , the treasury thinks the uk will end up having to pay about â£ 20bn .
here is an excerpt from tim shipman and bojan pancevski 's story .
the row over gibraltar emerged as treasury officials admitted privately that britain would have to pay brussels more than â£ 20bn to exit the eu .
prominent city of london figures were told last week that it would be hard to drive down the brexit bill demanded by the european commission below ¬25bn ( â£ 21bn ) .
a city figure involved in the talks said : â£ 20bn-plus is what treasury officials are putting around in private .
that has sparked fury among eurosceptics who say that britain should drive a harder bargain .
one said : the eu has no culture of making cuts .
without our money they will be bankrupt .
that puts us in a very strong position .
insiders say davis privately believes the bill will end up between â£ 9bn and â£ 16bn still too high for some eurosceptics .
to make matters worse , the eu could demand that britain pay even more than the ¬60bn the commission has suggested .
gã¼nther oettinger , the budget commissioner , told friends last week that the brexit bill would be at least ¬60bn .
accepting ecj rulings the uk and the eu both accept that there will be a need for a transitional period after brexit until a new uk-eu trade deal comes into force .
but the terms of this transitional deal are likely to be a source of dispute .
may says brexit must restore the supremacy of british law and remove britain from the clutches of the european court of justice .
but the eu may insist on the uk obeying the ecj during the transitional period .
respondents were asked about continuing to obey rulings from the ecj for a few years after brexit , as part of a transitional deal that eases the impact of the uk leaving the single market .

acceptable : 34 % not acceptable : 47 % do n't know : 19 % only a third of voters would find it acceptable to have a brexit transitional deal that involved the uk still having to obey ecj rulings during the transition period , a poll suggests .
continuing free movement but voters are much more relaxed about another potential compromise - extending free movement of people .
respondents were asked about accepting the continued free movement of people for a few years after brexit , as part of a transitional deal that eases the impact of the uk leaving the single market .

acceptable : 54 % not acceptable : 29 % do n't know : 17 % most voters would be happy to have a brexit transitional deal that involved extending free movement of people during the transition period , a poll suggests .

giving preferential treatment after brexit to eu migrants the final question was about giving some sort of preference to eu workers after brexit when immigration rules are applied as part of the final deal .

respondents were asked about giving some element of preferential treatment to eu citizens who want to come to work in the uk , instead of treating them in the same way as non-eu migrants after brexit .
acceptable : 48 % not acceptable : 28 % do n't know : 23 % only a third of voters would oppose giving eu migrants preference over non-eu migrants after brexit , poll suggests .
icm unlimited interviewed 2,005 adults aged 18+ online from 31 march to 2 april 2017 .
interviews were conducted across the country and the results have been weighted to the profile of all adults .
icm is a member of the british polling council and abides by its rules .
i will post a link to the tables when they go up online on the icm website , which should be soon .

documents.title: labour support at lowest since 2015 election , guardian/icm poll suggests
text: the latest guardian/icm polling figures are out , and labour has hit a fresh low .
at 25 % , their support is lower than it has been at any time in the guardian/icm series since the 2015 election and joint equal to their lowest performance in these polls going back to 1983 .
here are the figures .

conservatives : 43 % ( down 2 since guardian/icm two weeks ago ) labour : 25 % ( down 1 ) ukip : 11 % ( up 1 ) lib dems : 11 % ( up 2 ) greens : 4 % ( no change ) conservative lead : 18 points ( down 1 ) icm 's director martin boon says support for labour has only fallen this low only twice since the firm started polling for the guardian : in june and august 2009 , when gordon brown was prime minister .

it is hard to find much consolation for labour in these figures , but polls are only a guide to opinion , not a precise prediction of election outcomes , and one bonus for the party is that , in the local elections next month , it is extremely unlikely that the conservatives will be 18 points ahead on the equivalent national vote .

yesterday it emerged that colin rawlings and michael thrasher , two academics who produce one equivalent national vote figure ( john curtice produces another , using a slightly different methodology ) , are predicting that the tories will be on 31 % , and labour 29 % .
that is based on their analysis of voting in council byelections in the last three months .

so , if rawlings and thrasher are right , expect labour figures to pop up on election night saying that , although the results are disappointing , they show labour are much closer to the tories than the headline polling figures , like ours , suggest .

( it wo n't be an entirely convincing argument , because it involves a fallacious apples/oranges comparison - people do n't vote for a potential pm in local elections - but it wo n't be entirely irrelevant either , and it may provide labour with some comfort on the night . )
the icm poll also has some very interesting findings on brexit .
i will post them shortly .
icm unlimited interviewed 2,005 adults aged 18+ online from 31 march to 2 april 2017 .
interviews were conducted across the country and the results have been weighted to the profile of all adults .
icm is a member of the british polling council and abides by its rules .
here is my colleague jessica elgot 's story on theresa may saying that jaw-jaw , not war-war , will be the government 's approach to resolving differences with spain over gibraltar .
may says 'jaw-jaw ' will be uk policy towards gibraltar read more

the former lib dem business secretary sir vincent cable has said it is a fallacy that britain will be able to conjure up a series of new trade deals post brexit that will boost what he says is a fundamentally weak economy .
coveted trade deals with the likes of us and india are fraught with practical difficulties , he told the uk in a changing europe conference .
the indians had already sent theresa may packing over britain 's refusal to grant more visas to entrepreneurs and students , he said , while a deal with the us would take years to complete .
cable said he had a glimpse of the practical difficulties during talks for the now stalled transatlantic trade and investment partnership ( ttip ) trade deal .
the practical problem that arose was whose technical standards do you adopt ?
he said , referring to the differing standards that apply to food , pharmaceuticals and cars .

any car manufacturer in the uk would be horrified at the whole idea that they 've got to completely rejig all their machine tools and their production lines in order to adopt technical standards of us , with which we currently do very little business .

fears have previously been raised about the future of food standards with an exit from europe potentially paving the way for hormone-impregnated meat and genetically modified grain making their way onto british supermarket shelves .
people are rushing into this and [ talking about ] the wonders of these new trade deals they have n't even begun to think of the nitty gritty practical problems , he said .
sir vince cable at the uk in a changing europe conference .
tett/rex/shutterstock
bert koenders , the dutch foreign minister , called for calm in the row between britain and spain over gibraltar .
we see now how difficult the divorce is , he said .
let 's be cool and carry on and not use too harsh language .
let 's just negotiate .
in brussels there was no weakening on of the resolve to allow spain a say on the future of gibraltar .
the draft guidelines have the full backing of the european commission , the full support by president juncker and michel barnier , said a commission spokesman .
let there be no doubt about it .
this is a process on which we work very closely with president tusk and we are very happy to affirm our support to these guidelines .
asked to respond to the lord howard 's comments , the spokesman said : the european commission takes the side of dialogue and cooperation - which is our way of doing things .
javier nart , a spanish liberal mep , said that his country 's interest was to ensure that gibraltar , could no longer act as a tax haven to the detriment of spain .
frankly speaking it does not give me a second of happiness if the spanish flag is on the rock .
what is important for spain , and for me , is that this territory is not used as a fiscal base against spain .
no-one is going to back the situation of the united kingdom on gibraltar , it is unacceptable .
this jingoism from mr howard , that he wants to put on the battle-dress , is grotesque and ridiculous .
the degree of quality of the politics and politicians in the united kingdom is now at the level of farage .

documents.title: no 10 lobby briefing - summary
text: here are the main points from the number 10 lobby briefing .

downing street refused to condemn lord howard for suggesting yesterday that the uk should threaten to use force to protect gibraltar , just as lady thatcher did when the falklands were invited by argentina .
asked about howard 's comments , and whether the tone of them was helpful , the prime minister 's spokesman at first just stressed the government 's support for gibraltar .
then he argued that howard was just trying to show the uk 's resolve .
the spokesman said : all that lord howard was trying to establish is the resolve that we will have to protect the rights of gibraltar and its sovereignty .
but the spokesman was prepared to rule out sending a falklands-style taskforce to protect gibraltar .
it is n't going to happen , he said .
david davis , the brexit secretary , is in spain today , where this morning he met the foreign minister , alfonso dastis .
the spokesman said that this was a meeting that had been in the diary for a number of weeks .
afterwards davis will travel to portugal .

the spokesman said that davis did speak about gibraltar with dastis , and that he echoed what theresa may has already said about how the government will be steadfast in its support for the territory .
the meeting was very friendly and very constructive , the spokesman said .
the spokesman played down the significance of the draft brexit negotiating guidelines produced on friday .
the guidelines say , after the uk leaves the eu , no agreement between the eu and the uk should apply to gibraltar without the agreement of spain .
the spokesman stressed that these were draft guidelines .
the government would wait and see whether this clause remained in the final version , he said .
the spokesman refused to confirm that the uk would insist on any future uk-eu trade deal applying to gibraltar .
the draft negotiating guidelines imply that spain will try to exclude gibraltar .
asked if the uk would insist on gibraltar being included , the spokesman said he would not comment on the negotiations .
the spokesman said the government had been clear that it wanted a positive , constructive deal that works in the best interests of all parties .
the spokesman defended cuts to the widowed parent 's allowance coming into force this week .
he said that the government was changing the rules because they were introduced 90 years ago and had not been updated .
the system that was put in place then was based on the assumption that a widowed parent would rely entirely on the spouse for their income and would never work for themselves .
and that just does not reflect the situation of society today .
the spokesman said that the government thought china had an important role to play in containing north korea .

he was responding to a question about whether the government welcomed president trump 's declaration that the us may act alone , without china 's help , to tackle the threat posed by north korea 's nuclear programme .
the government condemned north korea 's destabilising activities in the region , he said .
but we have also said we will also work with our international partners to maintain pressure on north korea and obviously china has an important role to play in that .
the spokesman played down the significance of a guardian report saying scotland yard is examining allegations of war crimes by saudi arabia in yemen .
asked about this , he said : there is no met investigation .
what has happened is that they received an allegation of war crimes .
they are now conducting what is known as a scoping exercise , which is a different thing entirely to an investigation .
he also played down the prospect of human rights abuses in yemen being raised by the prime minister on her visit to saudi arabia .
the talks would mostly focus on defence and trade issues , he said .
yemen war crime allegations were not on the agenda , he said .
the spokesman refused to deny a report in the sunday times ( paywall ) saying the government is planning to introduce taxes of up to â£ 20 a day for diesel cars in some cities .
and in some cities diesel vehicles could be banned from some areas , the report said .
the spokesman described the report as pure speculation and said the government would set out its plans in due course .
the spokesman refused to confirm that the traditional blue british passport will be brought back after brexit .
but he did say that the passport was redesigned every five years , and he said the contract for the post-2019 redesign was just going out to tender .
some leave supporters object very strongly to the burgundy , eu-standardised passports that people are issued with now .
asked if the prime minister would prefer a blue passport , the spokesman said he had not discussed it with her .
sajid javid , the communities secretary , has today announced plans to spend â£ 40m on 30 projects that benefit coastal communities , the spokesman said .
10 downing street .

documents.title: cressida dick to start work next week as met chief , giving herself â£ 40k pay cut
text: sadiq khan , the mayor of london , has confirmed this morning that cressida dick will take up her new post as commissioner of the metropolitan police a week today , on monday 10 april .

according to khan 's press notice , dick was offered a salary of â£ 270,648 ( plus benefits ) , which is what her predecessor , sir bernard hogan-howe , received , but she has chosen to take a salary of â£ 230,000 .
so she has effectively given herself a â£ 40,000 pay cut .

the spanish paper el pais has more on what alfonso dastis , the spanish foreign minister , has been saying this morning .

documents.title: spain suggests uk needs to calm down over gibraltar
text: the spanish government is urging the uk to calm down over gibraltar .

as reuters reports , the spanish foreign minister , alfonso dastis , told a conference this morning : the spanish government is a little surprised by the tone of comments coming out of britain , a country known for its composure .
dastis also said , according to the financial times : in this case , the traditional british composure has been notable for its absence .
alfonso dastis .

boris johnson , the foreign secretary , is attending a meeting of eu foreign ministers in luxembourg .
on arrival , he said gibraltar would stay british unless the people of gibraltar backed change .

he told reporters : the sovereignty of gibraltar is unchanged and is not going to change , and can not conceivably change without the express support and consent of the people of gibraltar and the united kingdom , and that is not is going to change .
but sovereignty is not really the issue .
the threat to gibraltar is that it could be excluded from a future uk-eu trade deal , as the eu 's brexit negotiating guidelines issued on friday suggested .

documents.title: michael howard accused of 'absurd jingoism ' over gibraltar threat
text: yesterday , only four days after theresa may triggered article 50 , the public debate bypassed heated and accelerated headlong into surreal/barmy territory as lord howard , a former conservative party leader and former home secretary , suggested that the government should threaten the use of military force to protect the interests of gibraltar as brexit unfolds .

he told sky 's sophy ridge on sunday : thirty-five years ago this week , another woman prime minister sent a taskforce halfway across the world to defend the freedom of another small group of british people against another spanish-speaking country , and i 'm absolutely certain that our current prime minister will show the same resolve in standing by the people of gibraltar .

this morning jack straw , who served as home secretary and foreign secretary in the labour government and who shadowed howard in the 1990s , told the today programme that howard was being absurd and that he was guilty of 19th century jngoism .
he said : the idea of britain going to war , or spain going to war against britain , over gibraltar is frankly absurd and reeks of 19th century jingoism .
i doubt very much that gibraltar will be the deal breaker .

last night , on bbc radio 4 's the westminster house , dominic grieve , the conservative former attorney general who now chairs parliament 's intelligence and security committee , also criticised howard , albeit more tactfully .
he said howard 's language was a little bit apocalyptic .
even howard himself seems to have had second thoughts .
on channel 4 news last night , asked if he was seriously suggesting war with spain , he replied : of course not .
but he did add : i can see no harm in reminding them what kind of people we are .
yesterday downing street was refusing to comment , but there is a lobby briefing this morning where we may get a response , and theresa may is bound to be asked about this on her trip to the gulf .
as for what they make of this in the rest of the eu , god knows .
but , if we find out , obviously , i 'll cover it here .
the commons is in recess and the diary is relatively empty .
here is the agenda for the day .
9.30am : the uk in a changing europe conference opens .
speakers during the day include hilary benn , the labour chair of the brexit committee , and john curtice , the psephologist .
11am : number 10 lobby briefing .
and may is setting off on her trip to the gulf , where she will visit jordan and saudi arabia .
